School of Petrochemical Technology, Lanzhou University of Technology Lanzhou Gansu 730050 China The efficient energy conversion of hydroxide exchange membrane fuel cells (HEMFCs) is restrained by slow anodic hydrogen oxidation reaction (HOR) kinetics. Recently, Ru-based nanomaterials have emerged as the promising catalysts for alkaline HOR because of its much more attractive price advantage and reasonable intermediates binding ability, yet a comprehensive timely review on major achievements of Ru-based alkaline HOR catalysts is missing. Under the background, we aim to provide thorough knowledge of alkaline HOR on Ru-based catalysts, such as the developed mechanism viewpoints based on diverse experimental and advanced theoretical studies, the effective strategies to optimize both the catalytic activity and stability as well as the current progresses in the HEMFCs devices with Ru-anodes. Specifically, this review first covers three seemingly contradictive activity descriptors. In the following, the structure-activity relationship is shared to elucidate underlying performance improvement mechanisms. Then, the possible physical chemistry behind catalysts instability, including electrochemical degradations, oxides poisoning and CO susceptibility, is presented, and corresponding promising strategies for improving their stability are summarized. Next, the performance progresses of HEMFCs constructed by Ru-based anodic catalysts are provided. Finally, possible research directions for further enhancing Ru-based catalysts performance are suggested. Wherever is appropriate, our opinions are shared, hoping this review will serve as a guidance for the construction and development of efficient Ru-based catalysts for energy conversion. Graphical Abstract Keywords Hydroxide exchange membrane fuel cell Hydrogen oxidation reaction Ru-based catalysts Activity descriptors Structure-activity relationship Stability Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Hydrogen fuel cells have been widely recognized as promising power sources in transportation applications for the fulfillment of carbon-free or carbon-neutral due to high energy conversion efficiency and zero carbon emissions [1,2]. Proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) as a kind of hydrogen fuel cells have obtained the rapid development and reached a near commercial stage. For PEMFCs, catalyst coated membrane (CCM), including the cathodic catalysts for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), anodic catalysts for the hydrogen oxidation reaction (HOR) and ionic exchange membrane for conducting protons (perfluorosulfonic acid membranes), is the central component ( Fig. 1a) [3,4]. Hydrogen as fuels and oxygen as oxidants are supplied into the flow channels of anode and cathode, respectively. Hydrogen molecules are firstly adsorbed on the catalyst surface, subsequently, the adsorbed hydrogen decomposes and produces electrons (e−) and protons (H+) [5]. The generated electrons can travel from the external circuit to the cathode, meanwhile, the protons (H+) are transported by Nafion ionomers and membrane to the cathode [6,7]. At the cathode, an adsorbed oxygen molecule is reduced to water with the reception of the four electrons and the four protons [8,9]. Currently, Pt-based materials have long been regarded as the most efficient catalysts for both HOR and ORR in PEMFCs [10,11]. Owing to the slower kinetics in acidic ORR (five or more orders of magnitude slower than that of acidic HOR), more Pt-based catalysts are needed at the cathode, specifically, the Pt loading at the cathode is ten times more than that at the anode (0.2–0.4 mgPt cm−2 at the cathode vs. 0.01–0.03 mgPt cm−2 at the anode, Fig. 1a) [12–15]. To reduce the usage of Pt at the cathode and thus the cost of fuel cells, two main technical pathways have been widely considered: (1) Developing the PtM (M: transition metal) nanocrystals as the cathodic catalysts of PEMFCs at a commercial level by tuning the particle sizes, composition, morphology, defects and crystal-phase and so on to improve the activity and durability [16,17]. (2) Switching the operating environment from an acidic media to an alkaline media by a solid hydroxide exchange membrane, which is known as hydroxide exchange membrane fuel cells (HEMFCs, Fig. 1b) [18,19]. In HEMFCs, the hydroxide exchange membranes with immobilized positively charged functional groups (quaternized ammonium groups, guanidinium cations, phosphonium cation and so on) can conduct OH− from the cathode to the anode [20,21]. Hydrogen molecules adsorbed on the catalyst surface combine with OH− to generate electrons (e−) and water [22,23]. The generated electrons also travel from the external circuit to the cathode. At the cathode, an adsorbed oxygen molecule is reduced to OH− with the reception of the four electrons and the four water molecules [24,25]. When HEMFCs are used, less expensive Pt-free catalysts with Pt-like activity and long-term durability under alkaline conditions can catalyze cathodic ORR [26–29]. However, the anodic HOR in alkaline electrolyte turns out to be a significantly harder nut to crack due to ∼2 orders of magnitude decrease of HOR kinetics in base than that in acid [30,31]. As a result, a higher loading of platinum group metals (PGM) is needed to keep a competitive performance with the PEMFCs (∼0.4 mgPGM cm−2 in alkaline HOR vs. 0.01–0.03 in acidic HOR, Fig. 1), which re-raises the issue of high cost [32,33]. Therefore, it is highly desirable to develop anodic catalysts for HOR with excellent activity and stability [34,35]. Currently, various noble and non-precious catalysts have been developed for alkaline HOR [36–38]. Ni is regarded as the most active non-precious component, but its performance (mass specific exchange current density (j 0,m) of 0.6–24.4 A gNi –1, area specific exchange current density (j 0,s) of 0.005–0.35 mA cmNi –2 and a peak power density of 22–628 mW cm–2) still lags far behind those of PGM catalysts at present (j 0,m of 20–3365 A gPGM –1, j 0,s of 0.1–1.0 mA cmPGM –2 and a peak power density of 185–2150 mW cm–2) [39–41]. Among PGM, ruthenium (Ru) metal is recognized as a promising material for alkaline HOR because it makes a better balance between performance and price [42]. For Ru, it has similar redox property to Pt and its price is approximately 50% of Pt, but alkaline HOR performance of Ru is interior to Pt due to the over-strong binding energy of the Ru surface with Had and OHad, as well as easy over-oxidation even at ∼0.1 V vs. RHE under the strong coupling effect of between Ru 3d and O 2p orbits, where oxygen species (OHad or H2Oad) are absorbed in competition with Had [43,44]. The activity or the current density of Ru finally decreases to zero at ∼0.3 V vs. RHE with the formation of thickness oxide layer on the catalyst surface, hampering all H adsorption. It is required to rationally design Ru-based active sites to optimize the adsorption energy for all involved intermediate species, which is based on the accurate prediction of alkaline HOR mechanism. In light of this, it is highly desirable to provide a comprehensive review, including the alkaline HOR mechanisms (activity descriptors), activity enhancement strategies, challenges to catalytic stability, and the advancement in single cell performance, for guiding the synthesis of Ru-based HOR catalysts with anticipated structures and features to satisfy catalytic application. Several previous excellent reviews on alkaline HOR have been published in recent years [45–48], while comprehensive discussion about the latest insights into alkaline HOR mechanisms, the major research achievements on development of Ru-based catalysts for alkaline HOR and their corresponding structure-performance relationship, the up-to-data strategies in elevating the stability as well as environmental adaptability of Ru-based anodic catalysts in HEMFCs is lacking and hence urgently needed. In this review, the recent advances in insights of the debatable alkaline HOR mechanisms (activity descriptors) such as hydrogen binding energy theory, bi-functional theory and interfacial water structure theory are firstly summarized. Then, the key strategies of the Ru-based catalysts in the enhanced activity, including alloy, size effect, heterostructure, phase engineering, defect engineering, support modification as well as organic/inorganic functionalization, are shared. The corresponding modulation effects induced by the engineering strategies are pointed out, hence the structure-performance relationship is well-established. Next, efforts made to develop stable Ru-based catalysts, suppressing electrochemical degradations, oxides poisoning and CO susceptibility, are presented. Subsequently, fuel cell performances are provided. Finally, the conclusions and some perspectives on the future development of alkaline HOR catalysts are elaborated. It is hoped that this review will benefit the insights of the structure-activity relationship and act as a valuable reference for fabricating high-quality Ru-based HOR catalysts. 2 Activity descriptor The overall process of alkaline HOR is described as follows: (1) H 2 + 2 O H − → 2 H 2 O + 2 e − Which is accepted to contain three conceivable elementary reactions, namely the Tafel, Heyrovsky and Volmer reactions. The first step of alkaline HOR pathways is the chemical (Tafel reaction) or electrochemical (Heyrovsky reaction) dissociation-adsorption of H2 molecular to form Had. Then, the Had species react with hydroxyl ion to generate H2O molecule (Volmer reaction). (2) H 2 + 2 M → 2 M − H ad ( Tafel ) (3) H 2 + O H − + M → M − H ad + H 2 O + e − ( Heyrovsky ) (4) H ad + O H − → H 2 O + e − + M ( Volmer ) Due to the involvement of various species (Had, OH− and H2O) in the elementary processes, main factors influencing the alkaline HOR kinetics remain controversial so far. Specifically, the viewpoints can be categorized into three types, namely hydrogen binding energy theory, bi-functional theory and interfacial water structure theory. Development timelines of important breakthroughs in insights into each type of theory are outlined in Fig. 2. The key discrepancy of the three theories is whether the OH and H2O are involved in the reaction in the form of adsorption states. 2.1 Hydrogen binding energy (HBE) theory As early as 2013, a volcanic type of correlation between the catalytic activity and metal-H strengths was established in alkaline media, similar to the case in acidic media, proposing that the HBE can be acted as an important descriptor for the hydrogen reaction in alkaline media [49]. In 2014, Durst et al. found 100-fold lower j 0,s for HOR activity in base than in acid and the positive-shift of the underpotential-deposited hydrogen (H-UPD) peaks with the increase of pH. When the H-UPD peak shift (ΔE H-UPD) was turned into the difference of HBE (ΔE H-binding) and the difference of the HOR rate from pH = 0 to pH = 13 was calculated by Arrhenius equation (rpH=0/rpH=13≈exp[ΔE H-binding/RT]), a similar ≈100-fold difference in activity was obtained, giving further evidence to the opinion that HBE is sole descriptor for alkaline HOR and the strengthened HBE is the reason of the decreased activity [50]. It is well known that water is major species in electrolytes (55.6 M H2O vs. 0.1 M OH– and 7.33×10–4 M H2), then, the effect of water on the catalytic active sites might not be neglected. In 2017, Yan et al. suggested that water adsorption at the electrochemical interface is pH-dependent, which becomes weak gradually as the pH increases, however, HBE remains unaffected. The modified HBE theory, apparent HBE (HBEapp, HBEapp =HBE−ΔG 0 H2O), was introduced and they believed that it is more appropriate for correlating with positive-shift of HUPD peaks [51]. In 2019, based on in-situ attenuated total reflection surface-enhanced infrared absorption spectroscopy (ATR-SEIRAS), Zhuang and Yan et al. demonstrated that both the weakened Ru-H strength and enhanced water adsorption make the HBEapp close to the ideal value of zero for extraordinary Ru7Ni3/C activity [52]. 2.2 Bi-functional theory or OH binding energy theory (OHBE) Considering OH– need be involved in Heyrovsky and Volmer step to form Had and H2O, respectively, the view that the OHad formed by OH− ↔ OHad serves as one of intermediates in alkaline HOR process was first proposed in 2013 by Markovic et. al [53]. They demonstrated this opinion by investigating the alkaline HOR behavior on different metals, Pt, Au, Ru. The onset potential of the alkaline HOR on studied metals coincided with the formation of OHad. It was believed that the slow alkaline HOR kinetics is because extra energy is needed to bring OH anion closer to the surface with negative electric charge and favorable OHad can make Had be more easily desorbed, hence boosting the HOR process. Bi-functional theory for alkaline HOR comes into being, which highlights both Had and OHad intermediates participate in reaction and the design of bi-functional active sites is essential for enhanced kinetics. However, this theory results in enthusiastic debate because of the lack the direct evidence of reactive OHad intermediates [54,55]. Until 2017, Jia and Ma et al. captured the positive-shifts of Ru adsorption edge with increasing the potential from 0.05 to 0.24 V based on the in-situ X-ray absorption near edge structure (in-situ XANES) of Ru/C and Pt1Ru1/C. When the Had on the Ru6 replaced by OHad as the model was used to calculate theoretical Δμ (Delta-mu technique), well matching experimental Δμ. This observation provided the first experimental evidence for the presence of OHad in the alkaline HOR potential region [56]. Next, Mukerjee et al. as the proponents of the bi-functional theory raised a new question in 2017: what is the adsorbed formation of OHad on the catalytic active sites [57]. Inconsistent with the above Jia’s result [56], Mukerjee et al. proposed that Ru does not directly form OHad at voltage below 0.2 V on the basis of Δμ analysis but instead are a complex quasi-adsorbed hydroxide moiety (Ru-Hupd …OHq-ad), which combines with Pt-Had for prompting the formation of H2O bond at low voltage. In the future, multiple analytical techniques need to be used for more comprehensive conclusions. In 2019, Jia et al. incorporated the adsorbed hydroxyl-water-alkali metal cation (OHad-(H2O)x-AM+) formation to illustrate the alkaline HOR phenomenon that the Pt/C exhibits higher HOR activity in LiOH than that in KOH and NaOH [58]. The AM+ can induce OHad desorption based on the hard-soft acid-base (HSAB) theory, wherein Li+ weakens the Pt-O bond the least while K+ weakens it the most [59]. The weaker Pt-OHad strength leads to the slower HOR kinetics in KOH and NaOH, exclusively supporting the bi-functional theory. As a result, the so-called 2B theory, which combines HSAB theory and the bi-functional mechanism, underlined AM+-induced effects on the OH− transportation throughout the double layer region and was proposed to account for the HOR rates in alkali metal cation solutions. Then a remarkable advance was made in 2020, OHad intermediates were observed from PtNi alloy surfaces within the process of alkaline HOR according to in-situ electrochemical surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (in-situ SERS) and isotopic experiments. The oxophilic Ni dopant in Pt is verified to accelerate adsorption of hydroxyl species, boosting reaction kinetics in association with bi-functional mechanism [60]. Recently, the simultaneous acquisition of OHad and Had intermediates on RuOx and Pt sites for PtRu catalyst, respectively, further demonstrated the bi-functional mechanism for improved HOR activity [61]. 2.3 The interfacial water structure theory Besides the adsorption of Had and OHad intermediates, the dynamics and chemistry of interfacial water might also play an important role in alkaline HOR catalysis because water molecules are the major components of the interfacial electric double layer (EDL) and directly participate in the catalysis process of Volmer step [62]. In 2013, Rossmeisl et al. applied thermodynamic arguments to Pt(111)|water systems and revealed that pH influences on interfacial water structure [63]. Water orientation tends to change from H-down to H-up with increasing pH. In 2017, Koper et al. proposed that pH-dependence of the HOR kinetics origins from pH-dependent water structures at interface, which depends on the strength of interfacial electric field [64]. From acid to base, the position of the potential of zero (free) charge (pzfc) shifts positively to higher potential, far away from hydrogen region. The corresponding hydrogen region has strong electric field and rigid water network in base. The more rigid the water network, the more difficult the OH− charge transfer. As a consequence, HOR kinetics is sluggish in alkaline media. According to this view, the enhancement of alkaline HOR kinetics after the introduction of Ni(OH)2 into Pt is contributed to the weaker interfacial electric field and hence the more disordered interfacial water network. In 2020, Tang et al. confirmed the importance role of interfacial water in HOR according to a larger kinetic isotope effect (KIE) in base than that in acid [65]. In 2022, Chen et al. reported that pH effect of HOR is due to different interfacial water structures and thereby the different connectivity of hydrogen bond networks based on ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations and in-situ ATR-SEIRAS [66]. At alkaline interface, there exists a visible gap of water, significantly reducing the connectivity of hydrogen bond networks and hence severely impeding the transfer of hydrogen to the electrode surface. When Ru is doped into Pt, adsorbed OH species on Ru sites can greatly improve the interfacial water concentration and hence the connectivity of hydrogen bond networks, validating the vital role of interfacial hydrogen bond connectivity dominated by water structure in the enhanced HOR kinetics [67]. The same year, Wei et al. explored the relationship between the HOR kinetics and electrode-solution interface by AIMD and density functional theory (DFT) [68]. They claimed more H-down interfacial water is formed in alkaline electrolyte, making the solvated Had bond stronger stemming from the repulsive force between Had and H atom of H-down interfacial water, hindering the desorption of Had, then impeding the Volmer reaction of alkaline HOR. In 2023, Jia et al. concluded that water orientation in the first layer of interface shifts from (H-up)1st to (H-down)1st as the strength of interfacial electric field increases [69]. The introduction of Ru to stabilize H2O(H-up)1st or the addition of N-methylimidazoles with a negative charged pyridinic nitrogen and enhanced N…H2O bond to bring the H2O(H-down)2nd close to active sites is an effective method against the strong interfacial electric field in alkaline electrolyte, endowing catalysts with superior performance [70]. To better clarify the reaction behavior of interfacial water, much-needed in-situ and operando characterizations are expected to provide direct evidences for steady-state or transient models of intermediates. Although different theories are still in debate, current theoretical researches gradually approve that oxophilic species (OHad and H2Oad) similar to Had species play a crucial role in alkaline HOR catalysis and the three activity descriptors do carry scientific rationality in different specific system. However, there are still arguments about the alkaline HOR mechanisms. For instance, if HBE is the sole activity descriptor for alkaline HOR, why is it depending on pH? If OHad and H2Oad participate in HOR reaction, how strong are their strengths for the balance of their adsorption and desorption? (For Had, the optimal Gibbs free energy of H (ΔG H*) is zero. However, the reported hydroxyl adsorption energy (ΔGOH*) ranges from about −2.57–0.72 eV [71,72]). What is the optimal ratio among different activity sites for the adsorption/dissociation of H2 and the adsorption of oxophilic species? What is the adsorbed formation of OHad and H2Oad? It still needs to design catalytic interfaces for exploring mechanisms, in turn guiding the development of efficient hydrogen oxidation catalysts. 3 Strategies for improved catalytic activity In this section, recent noteworthy advances on how to engineer Ru-based catalysts with control over their composition, size, structure, strain, support and functionalized modification for significantly improving alkaline HOR kinetics are emphatically reviewed [73]. As alkaline HOR catalysts, kinetic current density (j k), exchange current density (j 0) and electrochemically active surface area (ECSA) are usually applied to evaluate their performance. Fig. 3 exhibits an outline of the major structure-performance relationship of engineered Ru-based nanostructures. In generally, the structure optimization of Ru-based catalysts can directly realize the modification of the electronic structures, strain effect and hydrophobicity/hydrophilicity, further improving the quality of active sites due to the adjustment of binding energies of intermediates and the energy barrier of the rate-determining step (RDS), and also increasing the number of active site due to the increased accessible active sites, hence accelerating the catalytic kinetics. Table 1 summarizes the alkaline HOR activity of various types of Ru-based catalysts categorized by different optimization strategies. 3.1 Alloying Alloying Ru with another element can optimize the electron distribution and surface features of Ru to enhance the intrinsic activity of Ru­based catalysts [74]. Two Ru-Ir/C catalysts (high-alloy Ru-Ir/C-20 and low-alloy for Ru-Ir/C-60) with the similar ECSA, but different alloyed state of Ru and Ir were constructed and contrasted by Ohyama and Satsuma et al. [75]. The approximate 2–3-fold increase in the exchange current density for the Ru-Ir/C-20 or Ru-Ir/C-60 alloys vs Ru-only or Ir-only, and the activity of Ru-Ir/C-20 is also superior to Ru-Ir/C-60, supposing that a high degree of alloy is beneficial for alkaline HOR. In order to understand the contribution of Ru-Ir pair in alloy to alkaline HOR, the catalytic activity of Ru-Ir pair was evaluated by theoretical calculation, which was more than 3.5 times higher than that of the Ru-Ru and Ir-Ir pairs [76]. Based on the Tafel slope, authors proposed that the Ru-Ir pair can boost the Volmer step via a bi-functional mechanism, in which Ru and Ir serve as the adsorption of OH and H sites, respectively. Similarly, ultrathin Ir1Ru1 alloyed nanowire networks performed better than that of Pt/C, consistent with the detected increase in the M-OH binding energy for H desorption as a bi-functional mechanism [77]. Further, Abruna et al. studied a series of carbon-supported trimetallic systems based on Ru, Pd and Ir for alkaline HOR [78]. Since Pd has a small solubility in Ru and Ir (only ∼10% Pd can be alloyed with Ir or Ru), the content of Pd in the studied IrPdRu/C catalysts is retained at 10%. Compared to Ir10-xRux/C catalysts, Ir9-xPd1Rux/C catalysts are active over a wider potential region, in that the incorporation of Pd can inhibit the formation of IrRu oxide. Among Ir9-xPd1Rux/C, the high Ru-containing Ir3Pd1Ru6/C exhibits the highest HOR activity with a mass specific exchange current density of 0.728 mA μgmetal –1, ascribing to reversible H adsorption/desorption and weakened H binding energy on Ru/Pd sites after alloying with Ir. Recently, high-entropy-alloys (HEAs), containing five or more elements, hold unique atomic structures and electronic configurations, which are conducive to tunable catalytic activity. PdNiRuIrRh HEAs were constructed via a wet-chemical approach, where Pd, Ni and Ir atoms were mainly distributed in the surface layer, sub-surface layer and third layer, respectively, based on machine learning-based Monte Carlo simulation ( Fig. 4a-b) [79]. Element coordinated with each other, indicating each composition is evenly distributed and varied local coordination environments are yielded (Fig. 4c). After thermodynamically favorable configuration of HEA was modeled, adsorption free energies of key intermediates (Had and OHad) were calculated. Both optimized adsorption strengths of Had on Pd-Pd-Ni/Pd-Pd-Pd hollow-fcc sites (Fig. 4d) and OHad on Ru/Ni top sites (Fig. 4e) are beneficial to alkaline HOR. Besides the incorporation of precious metal elements, inexpensive transition metal Fe, Co, Ni, etc., alloyed with Ru has been also explored in that it can not only modulate the electron property of active sites, but also reduce the costs of catalysts to some degree [119]. RuFe, RuCo and RuNi alloyed NPs were constructed on carrier via an impregnation-reduction method [80]. Among all investigated Ru-alloyed catalysts, Ru0.95Co0.05/C is the most excellent HOR catalyst, ascribing to a down-shift of the Ru d-band center after accepting electrons from Co, and thus a lowering of the H binding energy on Ru sites. In another study, an initial Ru-Ni candidate for good performance was screened by DFT calculations due to many sites with ΔG H*≈0 [81]. In contrast, Ru-V, Ru-Cr, Ru-Mn, Ru-Fe were not suitable for alkaline HOR in terms of ΔG H* values far away from zero. For Ru-Ti and Ru-Cu, there were predicted that less sites have ΔG H* values close to zero, corresponding to sluggish HOR kinetics. Consistently, experiment indicated that Ru2.3Ni1 NPs/C with a high extent of alloy performs better in alkaline HOR test than pure Ru/C. Adsorption of the OH reacts with Had both on Ru and Ru-Ni sites, improving HOR kinetics. Nevertheless, the trend does not cohere with Luo et al. that RuFe nanosheet shows the optimal activity among Ru alloyed with 3d M (V, Fe, Co, and Ni), which is explained by the lowest the lying of conduction band minimum (CBM) level and hence the strongest OH binding strength [82]. The divergent conclusion might arise from different morphologies or initial screening principles (in terms of H and OH binding energy, respectively) and hence more studies on the mechanism need to be performed. Moreover, the alkaline HOR performance of RuNi alloys encapsulated in O-doped carbon layer outperformed that of only Ru and Ni counterparts, verifying the importance of alloying [120]. Also, Huang et al. demonstrated that the intrinsic performance of Ru is enhanced through decorating with Ni [83]. HOR activity is related to the ratio of Ru and Ni, proposing that the lattice engineering of Ru with Ni plays a vital role for optimizing Ru-H binding energy. On the other hand, deposited Ni on the RuNi alloy surface favors the OH adsorption, a synergistic between Had and OHad effect and low energy barrier of water formation can be explained for a high kinetic mass activity of 1.79 mA µg Ru –1 at 50 mV (Fig. 4f). They then modified Ru-based alloy with doping strategy. Ultrathin Pb-RuCu nanoflowers (NFs) were fabricated by a two-step approach, in which RuCu NFs were first achieved by reducing Ru3+ and Cu2+ precursor with hydroquinone in olamine, followed by modifying with Pb (Fig. 4g) [84]. Among RuCu NFs with different Ru/Cu atomic ratios, Ru92Cu8 NFs/C shows the best HOR activity, serving as the optimum candidate for Pb modification. After the decoration of Pb, the electrons of both Cu and Pb can be transferred to Ru and hence a downshift of d-band centers for the attenuated H adsorption, together with Pb as an oxygen-rich site to strengthen OH adsorption (Fig. 4h), displaying a kinetic mass activity (j m,k) of 1.10 mA µg Ru –1 at 50 mV, higher than that of Ru92Cu8 NFs/C (0.63 mA µg Ru –1) and Pt/C (0.11 mA µg Pt –1). In comparison with these 3d transition metals (Fe, Co, Ni, Cu), Mo (4d) is also selected as a dopant to increase the number of active sites and tune intermediates adsorption [121,122]. For example, Luo et al. studied the effect of doped-Mo contents in RuMo alloy on the HOR activity and binding energies of intermediates. It was found that the variation in Mo content has negligible effect on HBE values, but OHBE gradually enhances and HOR activity firstly increases and then decreases with increasing Mo-doping, suggesting that an appropriate OHBE is responsible for the excellent performance of Mo-Ru-2/C [85]. In another study, Li et al. provided a Mo0.5Ru3 alloyed catalyst based on a sequential impregnation, freeze-dry and annealing synthetic route [86]. It was observed that optimal H and OH binding energies as well as reduced energy barriers for water formation, efficiently facilitating the alkaline HOR kinetics. Several researches have disclosed that Sn acting as the high oxophilic element can promote catalytic process [123,124]. Thus, the sluggish alkaline HOR kinetics of Ru might be boosted through the introduction of Sn. The ordered Ru3Sn7/C and disordered RuSn/C catalysts were achieved by a colloid approach using different Sn sources (tin acetate and tin oxalate, respectively) [87]. The activity trend of these catalysts towards alkaline HOR is ordered-Ru3Sn7/C > disordered-RuSn/C > common-Ru/C, with explanations that the addition of Sn component and periodic arrangement of atoms promote the hybridization of Ru d and Sn p orbital and strengthen OH adsorption. Currently, one component usually enters the Ru phase and hence forms a disordered alloy. Compared to disordered alloys, Ru-based intermetallic materials with highly ordered and homogeneous atomic environment may be promising to show a higher HOR performance, however, the relevant research has been rarely reported. In addition, the introduction of non-metal heteroatoms (e.g., N, P, S, etc.) into Ru lattice is another efficient strategy to induce strong hybridization between d orbital of Ru and sp orbital of heteroatoms, altering binding energy of intermediates [125]. Luo et al. achieved N modified Ru NPs through NH3 annealing [88]. The doped-N effectively optimizes the electron distribution of Ru, downshifting the d-band center and weakening the H binding energy, thus exhibiting a smaller ΔG H* for N-Ru (Fig. 4i). The experimental results display that j 0,m of N-Ru/C is 0.54 mA μgRu –1, higher than that of Pt/C (0.23 mA μgPt –1). The function of phosphating is similar to the above N effect for Ru-based catalysts on the HOR catalytic activity [126]. Ru2P NPs were constructed on the carbon support via a wet-chemical method [89]. The electrons are transferred from Ru to P, weakening the adsorption of H and strengthening the adsorption of OH (Fig. 4j), hence endowing Ru2P/C with Pt-like HOR activity in alkaline medium. Moreover, RuP NPs were distributed on N, O-codoped porous hollow carbon (RuP/NOC), which showed a higher CO stripping and a more negative EH-desorption peak potential, corresponding to relatively weaker OH and H binding energy [90]. In the free energy diagram, the rate-determining step for RuP (011) is the adsorption of OH with a lower energy barrier of 0.38 eV, while that of pure Ru (101) is H2O formation with an energy barrier of 0.41 eV. The optimized adsorption of intermediates arises from the 0.38 e– transfer of Ru to P, leading to a kinetic mass activity of 3.25 mA µg PGM –1 at 50 mV (5.5 times that of Pt/C). As reviewed above, the introduction of other metal or nonmetal elements into Ru can promote the HOR process through the alloy effect, improving the Ru atomic utilization rate. However, for multiple composition systems, it is challenging to attribute the enhanced HOR performance of catalysts mainly to the HBE or OHBE mechanism. Thus more studies need be conducted for basic explorations in the future. 3.2 Size tuning With the rapid advance of surface science, researchers discover that small­sized Ru nanoparticles (NPs) can expose more active sites to expedite the catalytic activity in terms of rich with unsaturated coordination structures and defects in comparison with bulk Ru [127,128]. For example, after adjusting the parameters of reduction temperature and thermal treated temperature, the size of Ru NPs ranging ∼2–7 nm can be achieved [129]. Among them, the 3.1 nm Ru/C with both metal crystallite and amorphous layers, leading to suitable unsaturated Ru atoms, has the maximum HOR activity. In contrast, Ru/C < 3 nm and > 3 nm display only amorphous-like structure and well-defined facets, respectively, corresponding to too high or too low ratio of unsaturated Ru atoms. Similarly, Ru with average sizes ranging from 1.35 to 5.95 nm distributed on Vulcan XC-72 was achieved by increasing the annealing temperature [91]. Ru/C-120 with the size of ∼2 nm presents the most remarkable mass and area specific exchange current density, arising from the good balance of the metallic Ru0 content and particle sizes, the large ECSA, attenuated HBE and enhanced OHBE. Besides a wet-chemistry followed by annealing method, atomic layer deposition (ALD) has been regarded as a favorable technique for synthesizing controllable metal NPs based on its self-limiting nature [130,131]. In order to further improve the large-scale homogeneity of NPs on support, a fuidized bed reactor (FBR) combined with ALD technique was adopted by Kwon et al. [92]. With increasing the ALD cycling numbers, the sizes of the Ru NPs increase from ∼1.7–2 to 3.8 nm and the structures of Ru NPs change from the amorphous-like feature to the mixture of disordered and crystalline state to highly crystalline characteristics. Experimental results exhibit that the 10 cycled Ru catalyst with the size of ∼2 nm has the best mass and area specific exchange current density. The size-dependent and volcano-type HOR activity is likewise contributed to the optimal fraction of the coordinately unsaturated atoms. Nanoclusters (NCs), which bridge metal NPs and metal single atoms, have appeared as promising materials for catalysis due to great exposure of active sites [72]. Ru clusters anchored on nitrogen dopants of hollow carbon spheres with a shell thickness of 10–20 nm (Ruc/NHCS) were provided by the pyrolysis of ZIF-8@PDA@Ru(acac)3 precursors ( Fig. 5a) [93]. The kinetic mass activity of Ruc/NHCS is 1.95 mA µgRu –1 at 50 mV, far exceeding that of Ru NPs/NHCS (0.243 mA µgRu –1) and Pt/C (0.555 mA µgPt –1). DFT revealed that all elementary steps on the Ru4 cluster are exergonic, while the OH adsorption and water formation steps on the bulk Ru (001) are endothermic, confirming that the Ru4 cluster is more favorable for alkaline HOR. And more notably, a large number of active sites inside Ru NPs or clusters couldn’t be utilized in electrocatalysis in that reactants are inaccessible. If the Ru dimension is further downsized to the single atom scale to form single-atom catalysts (SACs) under the interaction between metal atoms and substrates, the local electronic structure can be altered dramatically, allowing for maximal utilization of metal species and helping markedly reduce the metal loading in the catalyst layers without compromising the electrocatalytic performance [132,133]. The substrates for immobilizing Ru single atoms can be categorized into carbon materials and noncarbon materials, which can anchor the Ru single atoms by the formation of the Ru-light atom (O/N/S) or Ru-metal atom bonds [134]. Thermal treatment of N, S-codoped-graphene (NSG) containing Ru3+ leaded to the RuSA/NSG catalyst with Ru-N4-S2 coordinated environments, in which four N atoms are coordinated with one Ru atom and two S atoms surround this site (Fig. 5b) [135]. The Ru-N4-S2 as the active sites is much easier to adsorb OH and also has lower energy barrier to form H2Oad than that on the Ru-N4, boosting its intrinsic kinetics. The noncarbon substrates, for example WCx, with extraordinary anti-corrosion and favorable electron transport properties, are suitable for stabilizing Ru single atoms for alkaline HOR. Ru single-atom dispersed on WCx (Ru-WCx) had been achieved by the pyrolysis of the coordinated mixtures of Ru ions with dopamine and tungstate (Fig. 5c) [94]. The longer Ru-W bond length (3.08 Å vs. 2.71 Å of W-W) indicated that Ru single atoms are weakly bonded with the WCx, laying the foundation for remaining the metal-like coordination features of Ru sites (Fig. 5d) and hence weakening the HBE of Ru (Fig. 5e) as well as enhancing OHBE of W sites (Fig. 5f). Moreover, the down-shift of the d-band center of Ru can boost subsequent desorption steps of H2O (Fig. 5g). The resulted mass-specific kinetic current density at an overpotential of 50 mV of Ru-WCx is up to 7.84 mA µgRu –1, which is 30.05 times that of Pt/C. Compared to SACs, diatomic catalysts (DACs) can display a synergistic interplay between neighboring isolated metal sites via the d-d electronic interaction, decreasing the reaction barrier and boosting the reaction kinetics [136,137]. Xin et al. successfully synthesized Ru-Ni diatomic sites dispersed on nitrogen dopants of porous carbon (RuNi/NC) by a dissolution-and-carbonization approach [95]. Atomic-resolution HAADF-STEM images verified the presence of a large number of diatomic pairs with different Z-contrast and an adjacent distance of ∼2.4 Å on the matrix (Fig. 5h). Further FT-EXAFS spectra showed the RuN3-NiN3 model as mainly active sites (Fig. 5i). Obviously, j 0,s of RuNi/NC (2.69 mA cm–2) is superior to that of Ru/NC (1.69 mA cm–2) and Ni/NC (0.95 mA cm–2) reference with atomically dispersed Ru and Ni sites, respectively. In the diatomic system, OH– is firstly adsorbed on the Ru site, followed by two dissociated H are adsorbed on the Ru atop site and Ru-Ni bridge site, and then Had and OHad are combined to yield H2O under the synergistic effect between atomic sites (Fig. 5j). Moreover, Xu et al. systematically explored the HOR performance of single 3d transition metal atom-doped RuN2 monolayers (TM-RuN2, TM = Ti-Zn) with the ortho-N and metal (TM or ortho-Ru) atoms serving as dual-active sites to adsorb Had and OHad, respectively, based on density functional theory calculations [138]. The HOR preferentially proceeds through the H2 + OHad-Had + OHad mechanism on the pure and Co, Ni, Cu, Zn-doped RuN2, while the Tafel-Had + OHad mechanism on the Ti, V, Cr, Mn, and Fe-doped RuN2. The well balanced Had and OHad adsorption strengths endow Fe-RuN2 with the ultra-low free energy barriers and hence the ultrahigh catalytic activity to HOR. Thus the integration of different single atoms in support may open up prospective opportunities for the development of efficient alkaline HOR catalysts because various species Had, OHad and H2Oad are likly to be simultaneously involved in alkaline HOR pathway. 3.3 Heterostructure The construction of well­defined interfaces via heterostructure is regarded as an efficient strategy to regulate d-band centers of active components and optimize the electronic structure of active sites, affecting the adsorption binding energy of active intermediates and enhancing the alkaline HOR performance [139,140]. For instance, the heterostructured Ru-Ru2P/C was obtained by the pyrolysis of RuCl3 and NaH2PO2 as precursor ( Fig. 6a) [96]. The j 0,m of as-prepared Ru-Ru2P/C is 0.375 mA μgRu –1, better than its counterparts (Ru/C of 0.252 and Ru2P/C of 0.157 mA μgRu –1). As seem from the activity trends of Ru-Ru2P/C with the pH ranging from 1 to 13, the j 0 of Ru-Ru2P/C decreases as pH increases to 7, but rises when the pH exceeds 7, emerging an inflection point at the pH of 7 (Fig. 6b). The non-monotonous relationship is in contradiction with previous report that j 0 of Pt/C, Ir/C, Pd/C and Rh/C declines linearly with pH [141,142]. Therefore, authors claimed that influencing factors during acid and alkaline HOR process for Ru-Ru2P/C should be distinct. Remarkably, both the adsorption of H and OH gradually become strengthened with the increasing pH. HBEapp is essential for acidic HOR, where the stronger the HBEapp, the lower the activity. However, OHBE is responsible for alkaline HOR, where the stronger the OHBE, the higher the activity (Fig. 6c). The Ru-Ru2P/C displays the strongest OH adsorption due to the electron redistribution across the interface, corresponding to the highest activity in alkaline media (Fig. 6d). Furthermore, Huang et al. reported the Ru/RuO2 heterostructures with 2D snow-like structure and clear interfaces (Fig. 6e) [97]. The obtained tuned H/OH binding energy by the interfacial synergy leads to superior mass activity of 0.487 mA μgRu –1, much greater than those of single component references (0.0695 mA μgRu −1 for Ru SNSs and 0.0608 mA μgRu –1 for RuO2 SNSs). In another study, Ru-cluster modified Pd3Ru was found to be better performing relative to pure Ru and Pd3Ru and it was claimed that the reason behind this is due to the decreased reaction barrier for the Volmer step [143]. Recently, heterostructure interfaces modified with defects/vacancies have been testified to be advantageous [144,145]. For instance, Ru NPs anchored on nickel/oxygen vacancies of Ni-NiO@C were fabricated with Ru/Ni-NiO interfaces (denoted as Ru/Ni-NiO@C) after the annealing Ru/Ni-MOF precursor [98]. It was observed a gradual decline in nickel vacancies contents but an increase in oxygen vacancies as the annealing temperature increases from 300 to 600 °C. Both the appropriate nickel and oxygen vacancies are partly ascribed to the ideal performance of Ru/Ni-NiO@C-400. Their DFT results reveal a weaker Had on Ru, a stronger OHad in NiO and a better conductivity under the presence of Ni are another reasons for excellent alkaline HOR performance. Also, Yang et al. fabricated Ru clusters coupled with porous Cu-Cu2O@C catalysts (Ru/Cu-Cu2O@C) via the pyrolysis of Ru decorated metal-organic frameworks precursors (Fig. 6f) [99]. The optimization of hydrogen binding energy on Ru sites (Fig. 6g) and hydroxyl/H2O binding energy on Cu2O sites (Fig. 6h-i) triggered by electronic effects are displayed to delicate to the activity enhancement with a kinetic mass activity of 2.7 mA μgRu –1 at 50 mV, which is 24 times that of commercial Pt/C (0.11 mA μgPt –1). Interestingly, the new emerging heterostructures with Ru host modified by single atom sites provide a promising approach to effectively tune the catalytic activity of Ru-based materials. When Ni atomically loaded on the Ru nanocrystals (denoted as RuNi1 NC) were acted as catalysts for alkaline HOR, the kinetic current density was up to 4.679 mA cmdisk –2 at 50 mV (corresponding to a kinetic mass activity of 0.53 mA μgRu –1 at 50 mV), obviously superior to Ru-Ni alloy (0.796 mA cmdisk –2) and Ru (0.302 mA cmdisk –2) [100]. DFT calculation showed that the ΔG H* for pure Ru is 0.11 eV, the adsorption affinity is declined to 0.06 eV when the Ni dual atoms are dispersed on Ru host, which is further reduced to ∼0.01 eV if isolated Ni is introduced ( Fig. 7a). The weakening of the hydrogen binding energy will decrease the energy barrier for water formation as the rate determining step, in line with the enhanced performance of RuNi1 (Fig. 7b). Sun and co-workers provided an isolated Cr1(OH)x coordinated with Ru catalyst (Ru-Cr1(OH)x-1.1, 1.1 stands for weight fraction of Cr) based on a sequential reduction and deposition synthetic route for alkaline HOR [101]. The atomic Cr1 species, revealed by wavelet transform (WT) of EXAFS only showing one weak signal corresponding to Cr-Ru coordination without Cr-Cr and Cr-O-Cr signal, are mainly distributed on Ru surface and coordinated with more hydroxyl ligands (Fig. 7c). The Ru-Cr1(OH)x-1.1 catalyst shows the better kinetic current density of 25.5 mA cm−2 at 50 mV than Ru-Cr1(OH)x-0.6 (8.9 mA cm−2) and Ru-Cr1(OH)x-2.2 (16.1 mA cm−2) and all Ru-Cr1(OH)x-y catalysts perform better than Ru NPs (0.5 mA cm−2), indicating the important role of the incorporated and appropriate Cr1(OH)x on Ru surface in enhancing catalytic activity. More interesting is that hydrogen spillover from Ru surface to Cr1(OH)x is observed for the first time based on a negative shift of Cr-O-H bending mode (Fig. 7d), providing the direct experimental evidence of the optimization of Ru-H binding energy. Further isotope-labeling tests disclose OD− participates in HOR pathway and Cr1(OH)x is more favorable for the adsorption of OD− for reaction according to a phenomenon that both Ru-Cr1(OH)x and Pt/C catalyst have an H/D isotope effect, however, the effect of the former is less than the latter (Fig. 7e). When the Cr1(OH)x (16O) is substituted by Cr1(18OH)x, the alkaline HOR activity of Ru-Cr1(18OH)x becomes worse (Fig. 7f), suggesting that the hydroxyl species of Cr1(OH)x also participates in RDS. Combining DFT analysis, they further verified that the energy barrier for the Volmer step acting as the RDS of Ru-Cr1(OH)x-1.1 is much lower than that of Ru-Crm(OH)x clusters and the reported Ru (Fig. 7g-i), highlighting that the significance of atomic-level interface in engineering surface for alkaline HOR. 3.4 Phase engineering It is well known that Ru nanocrystals usually have two crystal structures, thermodynamically stable hexagonal close-packed (hcp) structure and metastable face-centered cubic (fcc) structure [146]. Generally, the catalytic performance of well-defined nanocrystallines can be influenced by the atomic arrangement of the exposed faces [147]. For example, Wang et al. contrasted alkaline HOR ability of the hcp- and fcc-Ru/C catalysts, which were achieved by different synthetic routes ( Fig. 8a-b) [107]. They observed that intrinsic activity of fcc-Ru/C is superior to that of hcp-Ru/C. It was revealed that the higher fraction of the most active sites and stronger OH binding energy on these active sites for the easier desorption of H are main reasons of remarkable intrinsic activity (Fig. 8c-e). Huang et al. provided MoOx-decorated Ru (fcc) catalysts (MoOx-Ru fcc) via a colloidal approach [108]. MoOx-Ru hcp counterpart was achieved through phase transformation induced by high-temperature annealing (Fig. 8f). The j 0,m of MoOx-Ru fcc is 1.66 mA μgRu –1, outperforming that of MoOx-Ru hcp (0.61 mA μgRu –1). DFT demonstrated that d-band center of MoOx-Ru fcc (-2.7 eV) is lower that of MoOx-Ru hcp (-2.02 eV, Fig. 8g-h), in turn weakening both H (Fig. 8i) and OH binding energy (Fig. 8j), hence enhancing performance. In addition, they tuned crystal-phase by changing the concentration of coordination agent. It was clear that the higher concentration of citric acid (CA) triggers orientated growth of Ru nanosheet assemblies (NAs) with fcc crystal phase, while hcp Ru NAs are formed in the case of using a lower CA concentration due to fast nucleation and growth rate (Fig. 8k) [109]. With changing the CA dosages, three samples with different crystal phases are obtained (fcc Ru NAs, fcc/hcp Ru NAs and hcp Ru NAs). Among them, fcc Ru NAs show the highest performance and the activity follows the sequence of fcc Ru NAs > fcc/hcp Ru NAs > hcp Ru NAs, highlighting the significance of crystal-phase toward catalysis. From the above discussion, we can see clearly that the recently as-synthesized Ru materials with fcc structure have the superior HOR performance than that of Ru/C control samples with only a sole hcp phase. Sebsequently, more detailed studies should be done to further identify which is a more active phase toward HOR, which would not only provide effective guidance to develop and design excellent HOR catalysts but also be helpful to unravel the catalytic mechanism [148]. 3.5 Defect engineering Defects, such as point defects (vacancies), line defects and planer defects, play an important role in catalytic behavior of materials [149]. Therefore, rational design of defects provides an alternative method to fabricate excellent catalysts. As a typical example, Wen et al. reported a sulfur-vacancies-rich RuS2 quantum dots on reduced graphene oxide catalyst (Vs-RuS QDs/rGO) using a combined sonochemical approach and subsequent H2/Ar annealing procedure [111]. By changing the annealing atmosphere to Ar, RuS2 QDs/rGO without sulfur vacancies was obtained as a contrast. DFT calculations verified that sulfur vacancies induce the exposure or activation of sub-layered Ru atoms for generating a near-zero HBE. As a result, the activity of as-prepared Vs-RuS QDs/rGO is at least one order of magnitude higher than that of the RuS2 QDs/rGO. Subsequently, Ru colloidosomes assembled from Ru NPs with an average size of 2.2 nm, rich defects induced by lattice distortion, and low coordination number were provided by a one-pot solvothermal approach using a soft formaldehyde as gas bubble template ( Fig. 9a-c) [112]. The Ru colloidosomes exhibited superior catalytic activity and faster kinetics relative to common Ru/C due to the optimized binding energies of intermediates, highlighting the positive role of defect engineering (Fig. 9d-f). Moreover, Liu et al. reported the incorporation of Ru into α-manganese oxide (Ru/α-MnO2) can elongate the Mn-O bond and produce abundant cationic defects, which hence induces charge delocalization, lowering material’s electrical resistance and exhibiting good electrocatalytic performance [150]. It is hoped that more exceptional defective catalysts (defective metal species or/and defective supports) will emerge in the near future, largely boosting the development of alkaline HOR catalysis. 3.6 Support modification The interaction of Ru with the support is another effective way to regulate the local electronic features of Ru active sites due to their different Fermi levels and work functions. In most studies, heteroatom-doping is used to strengthen support-metal interactions [151]. Huang et al. used a modified molten-salt hard-template method to synthesize oxygen-related defective-carbon-loaded Ru catalyst with interfacial chemical interaction by Ru-O-C covalent bond (named as Ru@C, Fig. 10a) [113]. The higher the annealing temperature, the weaker the interfacial interaction. Among different temperatures (280, 340, 400 °C), Ru@C-280 owns more strengthened Ru-O-C bond, corresponding to the more electrons transformation between Ru and support and the optimum HOR activity of a kinetic mass activity of 9.53 mA μg Ru –1 at 50 mV. Authors conclude that the strength of interfacial chemical interaction plays a noteworthy role in enhancing the HOR activity. Also, sub-2 nm RuMo dispersed on N, P-co-doped hollow carbon polyhedrons (RuMo/HC) was fabricated by a two-step pyrolysis of the ZIF-8@RuMo precursor (Fig. 10b) [114]. Its activity at 50 mV (3.83 mA μgRu –1) was about 25-fold and 13-fold that of commercial Ru/C (0.15 mA μgRu –1) and sub-2 nm Ru/HC (0.297 mA μgRu –1), respectively. Besides well-tuned binding energy of intermediates due to the modification of Mo, the introduction of N and P into the carbon matrix to trigger orbital hybridization and reinforce support-metal interactions is the other reason for the extraordinary HOR activity (Fig. 10c). Moreover, non-carbon materials such as metal oxides, carbides, sulfides, phosphides, and nitrides are typical supporters because of more various electronic structures and stronger metal-support interaction [152,153]. Among them, titanium dioxide (TiO2) seems great promise to be used as a support material for Ru NPs because of its hydrophilic characteristics [154]. Wei et al. developed a stronger Ru-TiO2 interaction catalyst (Ru@TiO2) via H2 annealing of Ru3+ saturated defective-TiO2 for epitaxial growth of Ru within the TiO2 matrix [155]. Compared with Ru/C, the Ru confined in the lattice of TiO2 makes the 4d orbitals of Ru highly occupied, modulating adsorbed binding strengths of key intermediates. More specifically, H2 temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) and O2 temperature-programmed oxidation (TPO) curves demonstrated a lower desorbed H2 temperature and a higher peroxided temperature for Ru@TiO2, respectively, weakening Had and Oad binding ability simultaneously. In alkaline media, the Ru/TiO2 catalyst presented a kinetic mass activity of 0.282 mA μgRu –1 at 20 mV, 15.6% higher than that of a PtRu catalyst (0.244 mA μgRu –1). Besides TiO2, the electrons of WO3 can be migrated to nearby sites through bridge oxygen, triggering the optimization of intermediates adsorption energy and in turn enhancing catalytic activity [156]. For instance, Sun et al. developed a hydrothermal step followed by annealing strategy to obtain the nanorod-like Ru-doped WO3 catalyst, in which partial W atoms were replaced by Ru dopant, correlating to a high defective oxygen content ( Fig. 11a) [115]. Adjusting the coordination state promotes the electrons migration from O sites to Ru, weakening Ru-H binding energy (Fig. 11b). Moreover, W sites can effectively adsorb OH intermediates, which interact with Had to boost alkaline HOR process (Fig. 11c). Recently, metal sulfides are also emerging as an efficient catalytic support [157,158]. Srivastava et al. synthesized N, Ru co-doped antimony sulfide (N,Ru-Sb2S3, denoted as NRAS) with a pellet drum bundle morphology using SbCl3, CS2, NH3, RuCl3 as Sb, sulfur, nitrogen and Ru sources, respectively, via a wet-chemical method (Fig. 11d) [159]. The AS without the dopant of both Ru and N and NRS without the dopant of Ru were prepared as references. This study confirmed NRAS owns more sulfur and O2– vacancy defects, which is beneficial for higher dispersion of Ru component (Fig. 11e). Further, the local electronic structures can be rearranged due to strong electron-donating property of N1s, supporting charge transport (Fig. 11f-g). As a result, the optimized catalyst exhibits a higher current density compared to Pt/C (Fig. 11h). Carbon can be combined with other materials, like metal oxides and carbides, to form hybrid nanocomposites with promising attributes for support applications concerning the probable synergistic effect to enhance intrinsic activity [160]. Yang et al. reported the synthesis of Ru/NC@WO3-W2C (Ru/NC@WOC) by pyrolyzing WO3 nanosheets and dicyandiamide under an Ar atmosphere, followed by depositing Ru on the substrate through polyol reduction method [116]. Ru nanoclusters are uniformly loaded on NC@WOC with an average size of ∼1.79 nm and part of electrons are transferred to WO3 due to the smaller work function (4.7 eV for Ru and 5.05 eV for WO3), forming electron-deficient Ru for favorable adsorption/desorption of H. Besides, W2C serves as a highly conductive component and WO3 acts as active sites of OH adsorption, jointly yielding encouraging HOR performance in alkaline media with a kinetic mass activity of 1.96 mA μgRu −1 at 50 mV. 3.7 Organic/inorganic substances functionalization It is accepted that the modification of active sites with the organic/inorganic molecules can also adjust the electronic structures of catalysts, resulting in the activity improvement [69,161,162]. Recently, Jiang et al. first achieved NH2-decorated Ru clusters (Ru/PEI-XC) by virtue of the nitrogen donor effect in the NH2 groups of polyethylene imine (PEI) [117]. The successful N-donor ligand was demonstrated by the restrained vibration of C-N stretching and N-H symmetrical stretching ( Fig. 12a). Under such influences, d-band center of Ru in Ru/PEI-XC negatively shifts and hence the degree of anti-bonding filling increases (Fig. 12b), which weakens both hydrogen and hydroxyl binding energy, showing a higher kinetic mass activity of 0.42 mA μgRu –1 at 50 mV compared to Ru/XC (0.37 mA μgRu –1) and Pt/C (0.26 mA μgPt –1). Luo et al. used the inorganic substance (sulphate) to functionalize Ru catalyst (denoted as Ru-SO4), showing amazing electrocatalytic performance toward alkaline HOR with a kinetic mass activity of 1.18 mA μgRu –1 at 50 mV, which was about 4 and 2 times that of Ru and Pt references [118]. In-situ electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements show that a smaller semicircle (lower Rct value) and higher double layer capacitances (Cdl value) in high frequency region as well as a higher resistance value (Rp value) at relatively low potential in low frequency region can be observed for Ru-SO4 compared to the Ru counterpart (Fig. 12c-e), suggesting that the easier movement of H2 from bulk electrolyte to catalyst surface, the enhanced coverage of oxygen-containing species and the declined amount of adsorbed H intermediates, respectively. In keeping with in-situ tests, DFT demonstrated that Ru-SO4 owns a shorter distance between H2 to the catalyst site and a lower the hydrogen binding energy (Fig. 12f) as well as a stronger oxophilic property, jointly accelerating the formation water as the rate determining step and hence enhancing HOR kinetics (Fig. 12g). 4 Stability Besides activity, the stability is another key parameter for an excellent catalyst with practical application. As for Ru-based catalysts, stability is limited by such aspects as the degradation and oxidation of active sites as well as CO poisoning. 4.1 Electrochemical degradations Recently, possible degradation reasons of Ru-based catalysts during alkaline HOR have been revealed as follows: (1) Ostwald ripening [163]. Ostwald ripening phenomenon primarily happens on the nanocrystals with varied particle sizes or poor dispersity, ultrasmall and uneven nanocrystals due to high surface energy have the propensity to dissolve and then redeposit on larger particles, reducing the number of catalytic-active sites and hence the catalytic kinetics. Therefore, it is desirable to develop Ru-based nanocrystals with narrow size distribution for alkaline HOR. (2) Leaching or dissolution of elements [164]. For example, although Ru-based alloy catalysts, namely Ru-Ni, Ru-Fe, Ru-Co, Ru-Mo, Ru-P, have been proved to exhibit higher catalytic performance for the alkaline HOR than that of pure Ru, the doped elements possess the lower dissolution potential and tend to dissolve under the realistic reaction condition, causing the HOR activity degradation. To suppress the dissolution of elements, Dekel et al. first made metal NPs preferentially be anchored on the ceria phase of the C-CeO2 support to performed stability studies as compared to metal NPs/C reference [165]. Metal dissolution tests demonstrated that the metal NPs decorated with optimized CeO2 exhibit a 10-fold decrease in dissolution. The improved stability is contributed to the anchoring effect of the CeO2. This indicates the strong metal-support interactions are beneficial for operational durability. (3) Carbon corrosion [166]. Carbon can be electrochemically catalyzed and oxidized by supported nanocrystals to generate CO2 during the potential sweep. As a result, the carbonate forming from CO2 in alkaline media could trigger the degradation processes of the dispersed metal NPs, resulting in serious catalytic activity loss [167]. Notably, the loss amount of catalytic-active sites in HEMFC is lower than that in liquid electrolyte under the similar experimental conditions due to no excess water and no alkali metal cation to form the carbonate, which gives confidence to develop durable HEMFCs. (4) Detrimental radicals [168]. Ru-based catalysts might be influenced by in-situ generated radicals under the HEMFCs condition, while more detail need to be explored as not much is known up to the present time [169]. Recently, Kruczała and Dekel et al. pointed out that the formation of stable H• radical at the anode during continuous HEMFC operation. More insight into the formation and effects of radical could help in taking one step closer to design durable HOR catalysts. 4.2 Surface anti-oxidation ability The cell polarity reversal induced by H2 starvation usually happens inescapably and so rises the anode potential during the start-up or shut-down processes of the fuel cells [170,171]. For Ru-based anodic catalysts, hydr-(oxy)oxides can be formed on the site surface as the potential shifts positively, which will block active sites for the dissociation-adsorption of H2. Therefore, the anti-oxidation performance of Ru-based HOR catalysts at higher potentials should be evoked special attention. In order to keep the stable current density at higher potential for Ru-based catalysts, four pathways have been employed. One pathway is to enhance the interaction with carbon-based shells/layers. Ru NPs with compressive stress and defective architecture in V-S-Ru/C constructed by a PVP coated two-step annealing strategy enable the up-shift of d-band center for enhanced electron coupling between carbon support and Ru NPs ( Fig. 13) [110]. As a result, V-S-Ru/C remains the stable current comparable with Pt/C during the potential exceeding of 0.15 V, while both common Ru/C and S-Ru/C prepared without PVP lose their HOR active sites, highlighting effectiveness of the support-NPs interactions in tuning the structure and electron features for outstanding oxidation resistance. The second pathway is to promote the synergistic interaction between metal/metal oxides. In terms of similar lattice constants of Ru (002) and TiO2 (101)/(004), Ru was confined and stabilized in the lattice of TiO2 (denoted as Ru@TiO2, Fig. 14a) [155]. Electron-enriched TiO2 can transfer electrons to the empty d bands of confined Ru, downshifting the d-band center of Ru and weakening the Ru-O binding energy as well as remaining a metallic coordination, thus unusually holding the excellent anti-oxidation performance. They further designed interphase-oxidized Ru (IO-Ru-TiO2/C) catalyst, where the Ru clusters were fully encircled by even TiO2 coating on a carbon support (Fig. 14b) [172]. IO-Ru-TiO2/C can stably catalyze the HOR even the potential up to 0.9 V vs. RHE. XPS and XAS results suggest that Ru clusters of IO-Ru-TiO2/C are interphase-oxidized close to Ru (IV) by TiO2 and hence half-filled Ru d-orbitals is formed. Therefore, further oxidation of Ru clusters is difficult, exhibiting a good anti-oxidation capability. However, it is difficult to understand why both Ru with a metallic coordination in Ru@TiO2 and Ru with an oxidized state in IO-Ru-TiO2/C can catalyze the HOR at elevated anodic potential. Next, Zhou and Jiang et al. contrasted anti-oxidation ability of three catalysts, i.e., (i) Ru-TiO/TiO2 catalyst without the nitrogen-doped carbon layers; (ii) Ru-NC@TiO/TiO2 with nitrogen-doped carbon layer sandwiched between TiO/TiO2 and Ru; (iii) Ru-TiO/TiO2@NC with nitrogen-doped carbon layer coated on TiO/TiO2 and Ru (Fig. 14c) [105]. Their stability exhibits the structure-dependency. The existence of Ru and TiO/TiO2 interfaces can avoid competitive adsorption of the intermediates (Ru and TiO/TiO2 adsorb Had and OHad, respectively), endowing the Ru-TiO/TiO2@NC and Ru-TiO/TiO2 with the outstanding inoxidizability. Then we believe interfaces of Ru/TiO2-x play a vital role in anti-passivation performance compared to the gain or loss of electrons of Ru. Inspired by abundant heterointerfaces idea, a series of Ru/RuO2 catalysts with different Ru0/(Ru4++Ru0) ratio or Ru/RuO2 interface content were prepared by solvothermal reduction of RuO2-x at different temperature (150, 180 and 250 °C, respectively, Fig. 14d) [106]. Higher reduced temperature results in the higher content of Ru metal, and then Ru/RuO2-180 owns the highest number of Ru(100)/RuO2(200) interfaces in that Ru (52.6%) and RuO2 (47.4%) almost give equal fraction in Ru/RuO2-180. As expected, only Ru/RuO2-180 can catalyze alkaline HOR from 0 to 0.33 V vs. RHE. The superior inoxidizability arises from the stronger interactions between Ru and RuO2 and hence electron-depletion around interfacial Ru, leading to a higher energy barrier for the coupling of Ru 4d and O 2p orbit. Besides metal/metal oxide, metal oxide/metal oxide can also enhance stability of Ru-based catalysts in alkaline media. Our group reported a RuO2-PdO nanowire networks catalyst with rich interfaces/defects and tuned electrons structure [102]. CO stripping peak of RuO2-PdO NWs/C shifts negatively to 0.575 V vs. RHE in comparison with RuO2 (0.659 V vs. RHE) and PdO (0.871 V vs. RHE). The DFT calculation exhibits the Gibbs free energy of OH (ΔG OH*) of defective RuO2 (101)-PdO (101) interface (-2.98 eV) is much stronger than that of RuO2 (101) of −2.29 eV and PdO (101) of −1.97 eV, suggesting that defective interfaces with the stronger oxophilicity can shuffle OHad on the RuO2, avoiding its over-oxidation and remaining the high stability (Fig. 14e). The third pathway is to take use of the confined hydrophobic environment to protect the Ru NPs from oxidation. The carbon support (Meso C) with mesoporous ravine-like channel is architected, in which SiO2 servers as the hard template [173]. Compared to conventional Ru supported on carbon surfaces (Ru/C) with similar Ru loading, the XPS signal peak of Ru/Meso C is weaker, indicating that Ru NPs mainly locate at the inner surface of Meso C due to the limited detection depth of XPS (Fig. 14f). No evident change is observed from the Cu-UPD stripping measurements for Ru/C before and after electrochemical pre-activation, and the contact angle value of Ru/C is ∼76°, representing the hydrophilicity nature of this catalyst. However, Cu-UPD stripping intensity dramatically increases after pre-activation for Ru/Meso C, reflecting the relative hydrophobic nature of mesoporous ravine-like channel before electrochemical pre-activation based on the hydrophilic characteristics of Cu2+. It seems that confined hydrophobic environment makes Ru NPs in Meso C be much less susceptible to air, H2O and OH– exposure than that at outer surface of Ru/C, showing more tolerant of oxidation property. The fourth pathway is to utilize the hydrogen storage strategy. It is well known that the Ru surface becomes inactive at the higher overpotential due to the formation of Ru-Oad species and hence the difficulty of hydrogen adsorption/dissociation. Therefore, the introduction of hydrogen storage materials serves as the H source might be an effective approach to remain the current at the increased anodic potential. For example, Fan and Li et al. reported an Au@Pd@Ru core-shell catalyst by a seed-mediated approach [174]. The longer the scan time for the HER, the higher the anodic HOR current for Au@Pd@Ru, but not for the Au@Ru and Ru, revealing that hydrogen easily enters into and is stored on Pd lattice. Interestingly, in-situ XRD shows that Pd phase can fully transform into PdHx under rich-hydrogen environment, and the PdHx phase will return to the Pd when hydrogen is deficient. Then they reasonably propose that the Pd can “transiently” store hydrogen at the interface in the low potential stage, and then release stored hydrogen at the high potential stage to Ru sites due to the deficient-hydrogen state, reacting with the OHad absorbed on Ru for remaining the HOR process. Moreover, authors highlight that the thin Pd layer is more promising for this procedure in terms of the good hydrogen transfer endowed by the tensile stress of the Au core. 4.3 CO tolerance ability Although the percentage of hydrogen produced by electrolytic splitting water will yearly increase due to the growing demand for clean hydrogen and the developing green “hydrogen-electricity” system, hydrogen production from methane reforming and coal gasification with inevitably containing CO impurity will remain the largest portion of the hydrogen market in the near future. Compared with hydrogen from electrolytic splitting water at a cost of $4.2 kg–1, that of hydrogen from reforming gas with 100 ppm∼3% CO impurity is $1.5 kg–1, showing an attractive advantage in price. To use CO-containing hydrogen or avoid the CO-poisoning from the carbon corrosion via electrochemical oxidations (fuel starvation and cell reversal) [175], some strategies such as weakening or even blocking CO adsorption by electronic effect, promoting COad oxidation by the interaction with OHad have been adopted to enhance CO tolerance during the HOR process. For instance, there are developed electrocatalysts owning the performance of both high alkaline HOR activity and excellent CO tolerance ( Table 2). Wei et al. first developed a Ru@TiO2 catalysts with weak binding ability to CO and unexpected CO tolerance based on an interesting discovery [155]. It was observed that Ru@TiO2 has not CO adsorption and CO-stripping peak in the CO-stripping curve. XPS and XAS demonstrated charge of electron-enriched TiO2 can be transferred to confined Ru, resulting in a high filling level of Ru 4d orbitals. The highly occupied Ru orbitals show a high energetic barrier to further accept electrons of CO by the donation process and therefore CO adsorption is hindered. With the existence of 1000 ppm CO in H2, the loss of the current density for the alkaline HOR on the Ru@TiO2 is only 12.4% after continuous test for 2000 s. Even the CO concentration as high as 10 vol%, the Ru@TiO2 catalyst still shows a catalytic activity for the HOR. For blocking CO adsorption, Zhou and Jiang et al. synthesized a carbon molecular sieve (CMS) layer coating Ru catalyst via a polyol reduction process, followed by a pyrolysis of Ru coated with polydopamine from 400 to 600 °C, which was named as Ru@NC/C-T (T means the pyrolyzed temperature) [104]. Different treatment temperature can tune pore sizes of CMS layers to allow selective permeability of H2 and H2O with the kinetic diameters of 2.89 and 2.68 Å, respectively, but prevent CO penetration with kinetic diameter of 3.76 Å ( Fig. 15a). As the pyrolysis temperature increases from 400 to 600 °C, the pore width less than 0.4 nm decreases while the pore width greater than 0.7 nm increases, indicating the ability to prevent CO entering decreases. As expected, Ru@NC/C-400 shows best CO resistant ability and all of Ru@NC/C-T have superior CO tolerance to Ru/C-400 without the CMS coating. Specifically, the relative HOR current density of Ru@NC/C-400 and Ru/C-400 reduce by 9.5% and 34.5%, respectively, after continuous reaction of 1800 s at 0.1 vs. RHE in H2 with 100 ppm CO-saturated 0.1 M KOH (Fig. 15b). Moreover, Ru@N-G (N-doped graphene) is calculated with a lower Ru d-band center of −1.94 eV than that of pure Ru (-1.89 eV), suggesting a weak CO binding energy for the former (-0.11 eV, but −2.08 eV for pure Ru, Fig. 15c). Benefiting from both physical and electronical prohibition of CO adsorption, Ru@NC/C-400 could remain high activity in H2/100 ppm CO. In-situ monitoring of the state of intermediates and catalysts during the presence of CO is important for enhanced resistance to CO poisoning. Note that the states of CO adsorption are classified into two types: bridge adsorbed CO (*COB) with weak bond and linear adsorbed CO (*COL) with the strong bond. Xu et al. observed that the current declines by 12.8% and 21.8% after 1 h and 3 h, respectively, in the existence of 100 ppm CO for Pb-Ru92Cu8 NFs/C, while Ru92Cu8 NFs/C reduces by 37% after 1 h [84]. Based on in-situ ATR-SEIRAS, *COL is hardly detectable in Pb-Ru92Cu8 NFs/C, suggesting a small number of *COL adsorption is a reason for improved CO tolerance of Pb-Ru92Cu8 NFs/C (Fig. 15d-e). When the integral area of *CO region is calculated, the adsorption capacity of CO on the Pd-Ru92Cu8 NFs/C is lower than that on the Ru92Cu8 NFs/C (Fig. 15f), indicating that weakened CO adsorption is another reason for excellent resistance to CO poisoning in Pb-Ru92Cu8 NFs/C. In another study, Ru@C-280 with enhanced interfacial interaction between Ru NPs and support via rich Ru-O-C bonds exhibits a lower wavenumber position confirmed by in-situ Raman spectra relative to that over conventional Ru supported carbon, indicating that CO binds more weakly with Ru@C-280 than that with Ru/C catalyst [113]. Consistent with in-situ Raman spectra, Ru@C-280 presents the much lower temperature of CO desorption peak (381 K) and higher proportion of active sites under CO-saturated to CO-free electrolyte (HUPD CO/HUPD) as well as the more difficult back donation of Ru d-electron to CO 2π* orbital compared to Ru/C catalyst, collaboratively demonstrating the suppression of the CO chemisorption on Ru@C-280. As a result, Ru@C-280 catalyst can bear 1500 ppm CO with activity loss of 9.1% for 2000 s and 20,000 ppm CO with activity loss of 19.5% for 5000 s. Pan and Sun et al. strengthened the adsorption of OH to resist CO poisoning. RuO2 is used to decorate Ru, the incorporation of RuO2 can form the electron accumulation around O in RuO2, which upshifts the d-band center of interfacial RuO2 and hence enhances the OH adsorption (Fig. 15g-h). When Ru/RuO2-180 with Ru/RuO2 ratio of around 1/1 exhibits a 23.5% drop in the current density at 0.1 V vs. RHE for 300 s in H2 saturated 0.1 M KOH solution mixed with 10,000 ppm CO, superior to completely inactivated Pt/C after the operation of 91 s (Fig. 15i) [106]. Moreover, Cong et al. reported a RuO2-PdO NWs/C catalyst with abundant defective interfaces, it had a 39% loss of initial activity after the introduction of 5% CO for 80 s at 0.1 V vs. RHE, while commercial Pt/C decreased by 94% [102]. This originates from more favorable formation of OHad on the RuO2-PdO NWs/C, accelerating the CO oxidation reaction. In another study, modified Cr1(OH)x as oxophilic species on Ru showed better CO tolerance than pure Ru [101]. Similar results were also found from NiPdRuIrRh-HEA, the strong OH adsorption binding energy stemming from Ni and Ru oxophilic sites was essential for excellent tolerance to CO poisoning [79]. A slightly decrease of relative current by 19% is observed on NiPdRuIrRh-HEA after mixing with 100 ppm CO in H2 for 1 h, however, a relative current rapidly declines by 63% for Pt/C. Also, Ru multi-layered nanosheet (MLNS) modified by Ni, dispersing Ni in the lattice and on the surface of the catalyst, can tolerate 100 ppm CO with activity loss of 24.1% for 3600 s due to the enhancement of OH adsorption [83]. Besides nanoparticle catalysts, the SACs also exhibit encouraging CO tolerance. For example, Peng et al. illustrated that the favorable adsorption of OHad on W active sites to fast oxidize CO protects the Ru (SA)-WCx catalyst from the serious CO poisoning (only a 5.65% drop) after the 2000 s operation with the 1000 ppm CO impurities in H2 (Fig. 15j) [94]. The beneficial OHad is demonstrated by more negative CO stripping position and zeta potential (Fig. 15 k-l). Xin et al. showed a small loss of 10% in initial current density at 0.05 V vs. RHE with the presence of 200 ppm CO for Ru-Ni diatomic sites, contributing to fast desorption of COad under the interaction of adsorbed OH [95]. Interestingly, Ru colloidosomes obtained via a one-pot gas/liquid interface self-assembly strategy exhibit an exceptional CO tolerance, 17.9% of initial current is lost after a 20 h test with 1000 ppm CO mixed in H2 [112]. Unfortunately, the enhanced durability was not explained in this study. 5 Fuel cell performance Researchers have made many efforts to develop Ru-based catalysts with the extraordinary performance assessed by the rotating disk electrode (RDE) in a three-electrode system. However, it is not clear if these catalysts can display the same property in single cell ( Fig. 16a) as that in RDE due to different operating environments. In HEMFC, the catalytic layer is a thickly porous structure with plentiful three-phase boundary, factors, such as ion transport, mass transfer, alkalinity level, pressure parameter and water/heat management, are crucial for single cell to achieve high peak power density and large current density, which are ignored in RDE [176,177]. In other words, experimental conditions of HEMFCs are distinctly different from those in a RDE [178]. Specifically, (1) The hydroxide ion transport depends on the tethered cationic functional groups in HEMs, the activation energy of hydroxide ion transport is up to 11.7–25.1 kJ mol–1, to be compared with no hydroxide ion transport by HEMs in RDE [30]. (2) Water is formed at the anode and consumed at the cathode in single cell, which causes a series of issues of HEMFC systems: (i) insufficient humidification at the cathode and high barrier for oxygen reaction (ii) flooding at the anode and then high resistance to H2 transport [179]. (3) H2 is transported to the active sites of membrane electrode assembly in the form of gas phase while in RDE measurements the H2 is supplied by the solubility in the electrolyte [180]. (4) The adsorption degree of the ionomer’s phenyl group groups on the active surface might be strikingly different between MEA and RDE because the catalysts on the MEA are under a humid atmosphere rather than in contact with an aqueous solution, resulting in the different exposure of active sites [181,182]. Of course, the methodology to evaluate catalysts in RDE has been well-established over the years, forming very robust and reproducible methodologies to properly benchmark activity and stability of developed HOR catalysts. After such initial benchmarking, the more potential catalysts can be integrated in membrane electrode assembly and studied under real HEMFC conditions [183]. The HEMFC performance of Ru-based anode catalysts are summarized in Table 3. It can be seen that the peak power density has been boosted from ∼0.13 W cm–2 to 2.03 W cm–2 in recent years (if not specified, H2/O2 serve as feeding gases), proposing that the great efforts have been made in this field and HEMFC is a promising energy technology. Ohyama et al. compared the performance of Ru/C as the anode with different particle sizes. As the particle sizes of Ru NPs decrease from 11 to 3 nm, the peak power density increases from ∼0.13–0.25 W cm–2 [184]. Shao et al. used a RuIr alloyed nanowire networks anode at the optimized anode and cathode dew points (60 and 50 °C, respectively), finding a peak power density of 0.485 W cm–2. The authors point out that the superior HOR activity and more hydrophilic feature of RuIr alloyed NWs are responsible for the performance of single cell. Further, trimetallic Ru6Pd1Ir3 alloyed NPs on a carbon support was evaluated as anode with 0.2 mg cmPdIrRu –2 loading in HEMFC [185]. This is the first time that the peak power density of HEMFC is able to achieve ∼1 W cm–2 using Pt-free Ag-based cathode (1 mg cm–2). The single cell performance of this Ru6Pd1Ir3/C catalyst with metal loading of 0.1 mg cm–2 (0.737 W cm–2) is close to that of Pt/C with Pt loading of 0.2 mg cm–2 (0.770 W cm–2). These results are exceedingly promising because the same power density can be achieved with 50% less PGM. When the Ru clusters (Ruc/NHCS) were integrated in the HEMFCs as HOR catalysts, the peak power density was 0.41 W cm–2 [93]. Even with the presence of 100 ppm CO in H2 as the feeding gas, the maximal power density maintains at 0.304 W cm–2. Xin et al. first assembled an HEMFC with Ru-Ni diatomic sites on N-C as an anodic catalyst, exhibiting a peak power density of 0.54 W cm–2 and slight decrease of the voltage after the 10 h test at current density of 0.5 A cm–2 [95]. With the anode composed of compressive and defective Ru/C (V-S-Ru/C), its peak power density reaches 0.567 W cm–2 [110]. Zhuang et al. reported Ru anchored into holey channel (Ru/Meso C) achieved a superb HEMFC performance of 1.02 W cm–2 relative to conventional Ru supported on carbon surfaces of 0.76 W cm–2 [173]. Moreover, the synergistic effect between H and OH adsorption as well as the negative potential of zero (free) charge are supposed to be responsible for the exceptional fuel cell performance of Ru2P/C with a peak power density of 1.3 W cm–2 (Fig. 16b) [89]. Although the power density of Ru2P/C is larger than Pt/C with the cell voltage decreasing to 0.87 V, peak density of Ru2P/C declines afterward, showing a lower peak power density than Pt/C (1.4 W cm–2, Fig. 16b-c). This suggests that Ru2P/C has the higher apparent activity in the activation region compared with Pt/C, while it owns the lower apparent activity in the ohmic resistance and mass transport-control region due to the surface oxidation of Ru-based sites.
