Similarly, another work by Jiang et al. synthesized NH2-modulated Ru clusters (Ru/PEI-XC) as the anode [117]. Catalysts outperformed the Pt/C above the voltage of 0.8 V and attenuated with the voltage further decreasing, showing a peak power density (PPD) of ∼0.7 W cm–2 at the current density of 2.5 A cm–2, inferior to Pt/C of ∼1.0 W cm–2. The fuel cell performance of RuFe0.1 NSs/C anodes is comparable with Pt/C at the high voltage region, but the peak power density of 1.2 W cm–2 is inferior to that of Pt/C (1.44 W cm–2) [82]. Therefore, the anti-oxidation ability of Ru-based HOR catalysts at higher overpotentials is worthy of more attention. Yan and Zhuang et al. employed Ru7Ni3/C anodic catalyst for HEMFCs and stability test, which can deliver a higher peak power density of 2.03 W cm–2 in H2/O2 and 1.23 W cm–2 in H2/Air, respectively (Fig. 16d), as well as remain 96% of initial voltage operating at 0.5 A cm–2 for 100 h in H2/Air [52]. It is worth noting that the HEMFC performance of the Ru7Ni3 anodic catalysts is comparable to that of the PtRu anodic catalysts with the maximum peak power density of 2.15 and 1.05 W cm–2 using H2/O2 and H2/Air as the feeding gas, respectively (Fig. 16e) [186]. Therefore, there are much potential for the development of excellent Ru-based catalysts as the anode for HEMFCs. 6 Conclusions and outlook At the beginning, we discussed the activity descriptors of alkaline HOR with special emphasis on the reasons behind approved theories based on the timeline. The developed theories can be divided three classes, hydrogen binding energy theory, bi-functional theory and interfacial water structure theory. The main discrepancy of the three opinions is whether the OH and H2O are involved in the reaction with the form of adsorption states. In the following, we update the emerging Ru-based catalysts with sub-category about the alloy, size effect, heterostructure, phase engineering, defect engineering, support modification as well as organic/inorganic functionalization. The relationships between engineering strategies, modulation effects, and catalytic activity are well-established. Next, the different strategies proposed to suppress electrochemical degradations, oxides poisoning and CO susceptibility of catalysts are summarized. At the last, it is highlighted that Ru-based catalysts without Pt composition could achieve comparable performance to that of PtRu/C as the optimal catalyst for the alkaline HOR. Although the significant advances have been achieved in the engineered Ru­based catalysts, there are still some research spaces for enhancement: (1) Monitoring chemical changes of active sites: Self-redox and surface reorganization for Ru-based catalysts might happen during the realistic reaction condition, however, direct evidence about the evolution is rarely provided. Direct operando techniques, such as in-situ Raman, in-situ Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (in-situ FTIR), and in-situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy (in-situ XAS), should be adopted to track the chemical changes of the active sites and disclose how such active sites work with the presence of various intermediates during alkaline HOR process, which can clear the way for both scientific understanding and practical catalyst advancement. (2) Using advanced theoretical calculation: Currently, most of computational models might be too simple and rough to really simulate actual experimental conditions because of neglecting of solvation effect, pH effect and external electric field. Efforts should be made to develop comprehensive computational models. Furthermore, traditional efficient catalysts are usually screened by trial and error, which is hard and time-consuming. With the remarkable advances in computing power, machine learning is emerging as the novel technique to predict the catalytic performances of materials based on thermodynamic and kinetic perspectives and enable the insights of the structure-performance relationship, followed by demonstrated experimental works, which is more favorable for establishing the design principle to effectively screen out the catalysts [187,188]. (3) Developing simple and economical synthesis routes: It is worth noting that most synthetic processes of alkaline HOR catalysts involve in the high-temperature heat-treated techniques or solution-based methods with organic surfactants, the practical application of the gram-scale Ru-based catalysts would need to take into account the factors, such as energy consumption, the size of reactors, uniformity of reaction parameters, surface cleanliness of catalysts and so on. Hence, future research should be focused on how to effectively engineer Ru-based catalysts with simple and economical synthesis routes. (4) Studying degradation mechanisms: It is no secret that developed catalysts suffer a certain extent of degradation during alkaline HOR process. Currently, Ru-based catalysts scarcely meet the stability target of 5000 h in terms of the automotive application, set by U.S. Department of Energy (D.O.E.) [189]. Therefore, understanding the degradation mechanisms of alkaline HOR catalysts in the specific three-phase interface, catalyst component, and catalyst layer configuration must be obtained for the development of the field. (5) Enhancing fuel cell performance: The alkaline HOR in HEMFCs only occur at sites owing three-phase boundaries, where electrolyte, H2, and conductive solid catalyst jointly exist [190]. Therefore, it is necessary to construct well-designed three-phase boundaries in anode to take HEMFCs one step closer to practical application. Comprehensive optimization of the hydrophobicity/hydrophilicity of catalysts, porous channels of materials and charge transfer property of solid support is important pathway to the design of such boundary. Moreover, the start-up or shut-down processes of the fuel cells inescapably rise the anode potential and cause carbon corrosion, and hence the anti-oxidation and anti-CO poisoning performance of Ru-based catalysts is worthy of more attention. In summary, the development of Ru-based catalysts for alkaline HOR catalysis is an exciting and promising research, which needs additional effort to enough realize their potential in HEMFCs applications. coredata.dc:description: The efficient energy conversion of hydroxide exchange membrane fuel cells (HEMFCs) is restrained by slow anodic hydrogen oxidation reaction (HOR) kinetics. Recently, Ru-based nanomaterials have emerged as the promising catalysts for alkaline HOR because of its much more attractive price advantage and reasonable intermediates binding ability, yet a comprehensive timely review on major achievements of Ru-based alkaline HOR catalysts is missing. Under the background, we aim to provide thorough knowledge of alkaline HOR on Ru-based catalysts, such as the developed mechanism viewpoints based on diverse experimental and advanced theoretical studies, the effective strategies to optimize both the catalytic activity and stability as well as the current progresses in the HEMFCs devices with Ru-anodes. Specifically, this review first covers three seemingly contradictive activity descriptors. In the following, the structure-activity relationship is shared to elucidate underlying performance improvement mechanisms. Then, the possible physical chemistry behind catalysts instability, including electrochemical degradations, oxides poisoning and CO susceptibility, is presented, and corresponding promising strategies for improving their stability are summarized. Next, the performance progresses of HEMFCs constructed by Ru-based anodic catalysts are provided. Finally, possible research directions for further enhancing Ru-based catalysts performance are suggested. Wherever is appropriate, our opinions are shared, hoping this review will serve as a guidance for the construction and development of efficient Ru-based catalysts for energy conversion.
coredata.dc:title: Latest progresses of Ru-based catalysts for alkaline hydrogen oxidation reaction: From mechanism to application
